messages.content: What is the purpose of the Code of Conduct for was-node-suite-comfyui?
The purpose of the Code of Conduct is to foster an open and welcoming environment in the was-node-suite-comfyui project and community, making it a harassment-free experience for everyone.
What are some examples of behavior that contributes to creating a positive environment according to the Code of Conduct?

Examples of behavior that contribute to a positive environment include using welcoming and inclusive language, being respectful of differing viewpoints and experiences, gracefully accepting constructive criticism, focusing on what is best for the community, and showing empathy towards other community members.
What are some examples of unacceptable behavior listed in the Code of Conduct?

Examples of unacceptable behavior include the use of sexualized language or imagery, unwelcome sexual attention or advances, trolling, insulting/derogatory comments, personal or political attacks, public or private harassment, publishing others' private information without explicit permission, and other conduct considered inappropriate in a professional setting.
What are the responsibilities of project maintainers according to the Code of Conduct?

Project maintainers are responsible for clarifying the standards of acceptable behavior and are expected to take appropriate and fair corrective action in response to any instances of unacceptable behavior. They have the right and responsibility to remove, edit, or reject contributions that are not aligned to the Code of Conduct or to ban any contributor for behaviors they deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, or harmful.
What is the scope of the Code of Conduct for was-node-suite-comfyui?

The Code of Conduct applies within all project spaces and when an individual is representing the project or its community in public spaces. It also applies outside the project spaces when there is a reasonable belief that an individual's behavior may have a negative impact on the project or its community.
How can instances of abusive, harassing, or otherwise unacceptable behavior be reported?

Instances of abusive, harassing, or otherwise unacceptable behavior can be reported by contacting the project team at opensource-conduct@fb.com. All complaints will be reviewed and investigated and will result in a response that is deemed necessary and appropriate to the circumstances.
What are the consequences for project maintainers who do not follow or enforce the Code of Conduct in good faith?
Project maintainers who do not follow or enforce the Code of Conduct in good faith may face temporary or permanent repercussions as determined by other members of the project's leadership.
What is the purpose of the segment-anything contributing guidelines?
The purpose of the segment-anything contributing guidelines is to make contributing to the project as easy and transparent as possible.
What should be done before submitting a pull request?

Before submitting a pull request, you should fork the repo, create your branch from 'main', add tests if you've added code that should be tested, update the documentation if you've changed APIs, ensure the test suite passes, and make sure your code lints using the 'linter.sh' script.
What is the Contributor License Agreement ("CLA")?

The Contributor License Agreement ("CLA") is an agreement that needs to be submitted in order to accept your pull request. You only need to do this once to work on any of Facebook's open source projects.
Where can the Contributor License Agreement ("CLA") be completed?
The Contributor License Agreement ("CLA") can be completed at <https://code.facebook.com/cla>.
What should be done when reporting an issue?
When reporting an issue, ensure your description is clear and has sufficient instructions to be able to reproduce the issue.
What should be done in case of a security bug?
In case of a security bug, you should go through the process outlined on Facebook's bounty program page and not file a public issue.
What license will contributions to segment-anything be under?
By contributing to segment-anything, you agree that your contributions will be licensed under the LICENSE file in the root directory of this source tree.
What is the purpose of the Segment Anything Simple Web demo?

The Segment Anything Simple Web demo is a front-end only React based web demo that shows how to load a fixed image and corresponding .npy file of the SAM image embedding, and run the SAM ONNX model in the browser using Web Assembly with multithreading enabled by SharedArrayBuffer, Web Worker, and SIMD128.
How can you run the Segment Anything Simple Web demo app?
To run the app, first install Yarn using 'npm install --g yarn', then build and run the app using 'yarn && yarn start'. Navigate to 'http://localhost:8081/' to see the demo.
What needs to be done to use a new image in the Segment Anything Simple Web demo?

To use a new image, you need to upload the image in the ONNX Model Example notebook, generate and save the corresponding embedding, and save the new image and embedding in 'src/assets/data'. Also, update the image and embedding file paths in 'App.tsx'.
What is the purpose of exporting the ONNX model in the Segment Anything Simple Web demo?

The quantized ONNX model needs to be exported from the ONNX Model Example notebook and saved in the '/model/' directory. If the ONNX model is changed by using a new checkpoint, the embedding also needs to be re-exported.
How is multithreading enabled in the Segment Anything Simple Web demo?
To enable multithreading, appropriate headers need to be set to create a cross origin isolation state which enables use of SharedArrayBuffer. The headers are set in 'configs/webpack/dev.js'.
What is the role of the 'App.tsx' file in the Segment Anything Simple Web demo?
The 'App.tsx' file initializes the ONNX model, loads image embedding and image, and runs the ONNX model based on input prompts.
What is the function of the 'maskUtils.tsx' file in the helpers directory of the Segment Anything Simple Web demo?
The 'maskUtils.tsx' file handles the conversion of the ONNX model output from an array to an HTMLImageElement.
